He's sort of the team leader for the eight interpreters sitting inside Studio E of Telemundo's headquarters in Miami.

A flight plan is how Cardoza describes a simultaneous interpretation.
That's when it happens in real time.
And it's challenging.
The interpreters were so focused last night, they entered into a Zen-like space, listening on their headsets while staring at a monitor in front of them for two hours.
I'm concerned.

Imagine that you are a pilot.
You know that your plane is going to crash.
You have two choices - focus on what you're doing and try to keep everybody alive or panic.
Cardoza doesn't panic.
He's been doing this work a while.
He says he's interpreted every president since Ronald Reagan.
Telemundo hired him to find some of the interpreters.
He says there are few things to look for in a good interpreter for a live event, like a presidential debate.
This is an art.
You want voices that sound pleasant, that sound accurate.
And you try sort of to match those voices with the person that is going to be interpreted.
Telemundo is used to producing real-time interpretations.
In early 2016, the network had to deal with fewer candidates, and they were all male.
This week's debates pose some different challenges, says Leticia Herrera.
She's the producer behind the debates.
What caught us by surprise - the amount of female in this election.
So when we have so many females, we really have to identify with different voices.
